data.title: Chasing the Luftwaffe. 1941 year, Polikarpov against Messerschmitt
data.meta_description: Indeed, everything that happened in the aviation design bureau of our country from 1941 to 1945 can be called in one word: the pursuit of the Luftwaffe. Indeed, everything that happened in our country's aviation bureau
data.text:
Indeed, everything that happened in aviation The design bureau of our country from 1941 to 1945 can be called in one word: the pursuit of the Luftwaffe.

Why with 1941, but not 1936? After all, this year the debut of Soviet aircraft in opposition to the Germans in the sky of Spain took place. And the conclusions were already made then, but we’ll go with 1941 in order, all the more so since virtually all “old acquaintances” met in our sky.

Quite intentionally we will not compare here the numbers of the performance characteristics, leaving room for combat performance. It makes no sense to compare, for example, the maximum speeds obtained as a result of testing in favorable conditions, if the combat speeds of the aircraft differed significantly from them. And the difference was from 30 to 70 km / h.

The main fighter of the Luftwaffe at the beginning of World War II was the Messerschmitt Bf-109, an all-metal monoplane with a retractable undercarriage, a enclosed cockpit, and a two-row, liquid-cooled X-cylinder. Created in 12, before the outbreak of war with the Soviet Union, he managed to undergo a whole series of upgrades, primarily with the aim of improving flight performance.

Hereinafter, the text will still be called "Messerschmitt" as Me-109, and not Bf-109. Although both designations are recognized as correct (since both one and the other are found in the factory documentation of the 2 World War I period), Me-109 seems to be a more correct designation of this type, at least since July 1938, when Bayerische Flugzeugwerke changed its name to Messerschmitt AG.

22 June 1941, in service with the front parts of the German Air Force (Luftwaffe) consisted of two modifications of this fighter - Me-109E and Me-109F.

Of the total number of 1026 single Messerschmitts concentrated by the evening of 21 on June at the Soviet borders, the latest versions of 579 (56,4%) were Me-109F-1 and Me-109F-2, which were launched into mass production at the beginning of 1941.

The 264 Messerschmitt of the earlier Me-109E-4, E-7 and E-8 models were also located there. Also, the 183 aircraft of the obsolete E-1 and E-3 models were part of the so-called combat training groups, which were considered part of the second line and, as a rule, did not participate in combat operations.

So, Emily and Friedrichs became the main shock mass of the Luftwaffe, the aircraft were very successful and sophisticated, with cannon and machine gun weapons (2XXNNXX-mm + 20X2-mm + mm and 7,92X1-mm + 20X2-mm), respectively; h and equipped with the latest technology: radio stations, fuel injection systems in engines and so on.

What was on our side?

Let's immediately agree to look at things soberly and call them by their proper names. If so, then on our side everything was far from ideal.

On the eve of the war, the most massive fighter in the Soviet air force was the I-16.

As of 1 June, 1941 was in service with five Western military districts (Leningrad, Baltic, Western Special, Kiev Special and Odessa), which were to be the first to meet the enemy, was a 1771 aircraft of this type. This accounted for more than 41% of the total number of fighters concentrated on the western border of the Soviet Union (4226 machines).

Approximately the same was the percentage of I-16 in naval aviation: in the air forces of the Northern, Baltic and Black Sea fleets there were 334 aircraft, that is, about 43% of the total number of sea fighters (778 aircraft).

The 16, developed in 1933 under the guidance of N. N. Polikarpov, was undoubtedly a very advanced and promising machine. For its time and in light of the state of the Soviet aviation industry.

Monoplane mixed design with a nine-cylinder radial engine air cooling and retractable (the first in the USSR, and in the world too) chassis.

Throughout its stories And-16 was repeatedly upgraded, almost every year new versions of this machine appeared and were put into service. The full information on the pre-war presence in the I-16 parts with a breakdown by modifications was not preserved, but based on the available data, it can be concluded that most of them (around 40%) were the latest and most advanced members of the I-16 family with 900- powerful engines M-63, which had the designation "type 24" and "type 29".

I-16 type 29

In second place in numbers (approximately 22%) were 16 X-NUMX and 5 X-types with low-power X-NUMX-powerful M-10 motors. Even less (about 730%) were cannon-type 25 and 18, 16 and 17. The remaining 27% mainly accounted for double training UTI-28.

It is worth noting that the I-16 and Me-109 were created at the end of the biplane era and both were knocked out of the general range of their contemporaries.

This was explained primarily by the fact that their creators aimed primarily at achieving the highest speed and climb rate, although this desire to a certain extent impeded the provision of good horizontal maneuverability and takeoff and landing characteristics.

But unlike the German colleague, Polikarpov decided to follow the path of maximally reducing the geometric dimensions of the machine for the sake of losing weight and reducing aerodynamic drag. As a result, he turned out perhaps the shortest fighter of the Second World War since the thick barrel-shaped fuselage. But the maneuverability of the I-16 has become the talk of the town.

As well as the complexity in the development and management.

Nevertheless, the 16 had an almost optimal combination of speed and maneuverability. The main serial modifications accelerated to 450 - 470 km / h and performed the turn in 16 — 18 seconds. It was necessary to pay for this with excessive maneuverability, the 16 suffered from the so-called yaw, it was difficult to drive it in a straight line, and this made it very difficult to aim, leading to frequent misses and increased ammunition consumption.

Here it is worth mentioning what the pilots of that war spoke about in their memoirs. About combat speed.

Maximum speed was measured very simply: at the height that was more convenient for the engine, in horizontal flight. Combat speed is a bit different. This is the speed that a plane can pick up in a limited time and at which the plane can perform combat evolutions.

The combat speeds of the I-16 and Me-109E were quite comparable, but the I-16 had the advantage in maneuver, both horizontal and vertical. Only on the dive, the Me-109 had an advantage, and the X-NUMX was hampered by a thick forehead.

Me-109F, despite the fact that they are heavier than the later modifications of the And-16 by more than half a ton, due to more powerful engines and better aerodynamics, they far exceeded the And-16 in rate of climb, altitude and speed.

This superiority was objectively a decisive factor in air combat, and it could not be compensated for by any tactical methods. Thanks to him, the German pilots owned the initiative - they could catch up with the enemy, rapidly attack from above or behind, and then again go up to the height for a new attack, without fear that the enemy would “hang on their tail”. The I-16 pilots could only passively defend themselves, dodging attacks due to the good maneuverability of their aircraft, and mutually cover each other, becoming in the “defensive circle”.

The defensive circle became classics of combat use for aircraft such as I-16, I-153, Hurricane, LaGG-3. Unfortunately.

Armament. Here the Germans also had a complete advantage. The most valuable feature is the weight of the second onboard volley.

Me-109E-4 had two wing 20-millimeter MGFF guns and two synchronous 7,92-mm MG-17 machine guns. The mass of a second salvo was approximately 2,37 kg.

The most massive modification of the I-16 type 24 was armed with two synchronous and two wing ShKAS machine guns of caliber 7,62-mm with a total weight of a second salvo of 1,43 kg.

The 16 type 29 carried three synchronous machine guns: two ShKAS and one BS caliber 12,7-mm. The mass of the second salvo of this fighter is even less - 1,35 kg.

Plus Messerschmitt was very stable armory a platform. In addition, the ammunition load of the machine guns of the German fighter was 1000 rounds per barrel and 60 rounds per gun, and the I-16 had 450 rounds per each ShKAS and 250 rounds per BS.

The “cannon” modifications of the 16 - type 17, 27 and 28 had weapons similar to the Me-109-4. Two wing 20-millimeter ShVAK guns and two synchronous ShKAS machine guns. However, due to the higher rate of fire of Soviet air guns and air cannons, the mass of a second volley was higher - 3,26 kg.

Unfortunately, such fighters were released relatively few - 690 pieces, and not all survived before the war with Germany.

Armament "Frederick" at first glance, was weaker than the "Emile". In order to facilitate the car, the Germans abandoned the wing guns, replacing them with a single cannon motor installed between the engine cylinder blocks and firing through the hollow axis of the propeller.

Ha Me-109F-1 it was all the same MG-FF, and on the F-2 already installed a new 15-millimeter gun MG-151 / 15 with ammunition in 200 shells. With respect to MG-FF, it had a higher rate of fire and better ballistic characteristics. Nevertheless, the mass of the fighter’s second volley fell, making only 109 kg for the Me-2F-1,04, that is, even less than for the purely machine gun versions of the I-16.

True, the effective firing range was higher and the accuracy of the gun installed in the center of the aircraft was incomparable with the two wing cannons.

In addition, starting with the modification of the Me-109F-4, it became possible to install under the wings two additional MG-151 / 20 guns (MG-151 / 15 with a new 20-mm caliber trunk) in special streamlined containers. Containers were easily suspended and removed in field conditions by aerodrome personnel. Such a refinement increased the fighter’s second volley mass more than tripled - to 3,6 kg, however it worsened its flight data and, according to pilots testimony, had a negative impact on controllability.

When comparing the combat potentials of the I-16 and Me-109, it is necessary to dwell on one more important point. By the beginning of the Second World War, all Messerschmitts were radioed and had on board quite reliable and reliable receiving and transmitting radio stations FuG-7.

This allowed the German pilots to coordinate their actions during the battle, warn each other about the danger or detection of targets, as well as receive commands and targeting from ground guidance centers.

The overwhelming majority of Soviet pilots did not have such capabilities. Of the almost three thousand I-16, which were in early June 1941 in service with the Soviet Air Force, the radio station RSI-3 "Eagle" had no more than a hundred and fifty.

And although the 16 type 29, released in the 1940 year, had special compartments for walkie-talkies behind the cabs, almost all of them were empty, since the radio plants could not provide the supply. Yes, and on the few machines on which the Eagles stood, it was almost impossible to use them due to the low reliability and poor noise immunity of these stations.

Despite the fact that their range, according to factory documentation, was 150 km, due to interference from the engine ignition system and other aircraft electrical equipment, the actual reception range did not usually exceed 30 kilometers, and the pilots usually heard only cod hissing in headphones ...

The second fighter Polikarpov, who also accounted for a significant percentage in the payroll of the pre-war Soviet Air Force - half-plan I-153, nicknamed "gull".

Taking into account several assault air regiments in the western military districts, by June 1941 there were about one and a half thousand “gulls”, or approximately 35% of the total number of fighters.

Despite the fact that the aircraft was designed in 1938 year, its design and aerodynamic scheme roughly corresponded to the level of development of aircraft industry a decade ago. The only progressive element in the “seagull” can be called a retractable landing gear.

In fact, the 153 was anachronistic at the time of its creation, and its launch into the 1939 series at first glance resembles an error. However, this was a necessary measure due to the lack of a better replacement for the even more archaic I-15bis biplane, which had to be urgently removed from production. Since the “seagull” had a design similar to it in many respects, its production was quickly and inexpensively adjusted at the same factory and with the same production equipment.

On the majority of serial I-153 there were M-63 engines and the same armament as on the I-16 type 24. Despite the fact that the design of the I-153 is completely different than that of the I-16, the take-off weight of both cars was almost the same: the 1880 kg of the I-16 type 24 and 1890 kg of the “seagull”.

However, due to the worst aerodynamics, the maximum speed of the “seagull” is lower: on the ground - only 370 km / h., And at the height of 5000 m - 435-440 km / h.

This speed did not allow her to successfully fight the German fighters, and often - even intercept the bombers. But the load on the area of ​​the “seagull” is significantly less than that of the “donkey”, which means that the horizontal maneuverability is better. The full turn at the height of 1000 m aircraft performed for 13 - 14 seconds. The rate of climb of both cars is about equal - 14,7-15 m / s.

The negative quality of the I-153 compared to monoplane fighters was a much worse forward look, blocked by the upper wing. Although Polikarpov tried to correct this defect, giving the wing a characteristic break for which the aircraft got its nickname, much of the front hemisphere was hidden from the pilot's eyes, interfering with the search and tracking of the target.

Because of the speed data that is even lower than that of the I-16, the “seagulls” could not use offensive tactics in fights with “Messerschmitts”. They could not escape from attacks due to speed. When meeting with German fighters, their pilots had to stand in a defensive circle or maneuver haphazardly, dodging from under fire and hoping that the enemy would sooner or later lag behind. Naturally, such a tactic, which received the official name of "bee swarm", gave the initiative to the enemy, giving him complete freedom of action.

The futility of airborne “gulls” forced them to be transferred to assault and light bombing regiments, although their weapons (four ShKAS machine guns and two 25-kilogram or 50-kilogram bombs) were clearly weak for ground-based attacks, and anti-aircraft fire was virtually absent .

By the end of 1941, the number of I-153 in combat units was reduced to 200 machines, and a year later they almost completely disappeared from the Soviet-German front. The moral obsolescence and futility of the 16 and 153 became clear to the Soviet leadership in the 1939 year, after the battles in Spain, and especially on Khalkhin Gol, where the Japanese fighters, which we had not taken seriously before, were suddenly very threatening for ours adversary.

Is it possible to say here about a certain short-sightedness of the command of the Red Army Air Force or to reproach Stalin personally, as is usually done?

No you can not.

The answer after conflicts with the Japanese followed immediately. In several KB unfolded hastily work on the creation of a new generation of fighters. As a result, the famous “triad” appeared - I-26 (Yak-1), I-200 (MiG-3) and I-301 (LaGG-3).

But about these cars - in the next part. These aircraft were already a completely different concept.

Speaking about the superiority of the Luftwaffe over the Red Army air force in the first months of the war, it is worth confirming the fact that the Germans were superior not quantitatively but qualitatively. It is according to the principle formulated by Pokryshkin "height-speed-maneuver-fire."

Was it possible to take a number? About 5 000 and-16 and and-153 against a thousand with a small Me-109?

Theoretically, yes. Almost ... Doubtful. Possessing more speed, altitude, more powerful weapons, well-radiated, and, most importantly, having more experience in combat use and more modern tactics, German pilots should not have given our chances of success.

They did not provide.

And with maximum efficiency they used all the trumps they had. From the combat qualities of aircraft, to the training of German pilots. On the training of pilots should be said separately, this topic can explain a lot of what happened at the beginning of the war.

As a result, it is worthwhile to once again conclude that the first stage of the struggle of the Luftwaffe and the Air Force of the Red Army remained for the Luftwaffe, despite the numerical superiority of the Soviet Air Force. The numerical superiority of the Soviet fighters did not play a proper role over the more advanced German fighters.

In the second part, we will discuss the Soviet "triad", the aircraft of the new generation, which, taking the first blow together with the Polikarpov fighters, continued the war for supremacy in the sky of the Great Patriotic War.

Sources:

Kondratyev Vyacheslav. Comparative analysis of designs and flight data of Soviet and German fighters who took part in the Great Patriotic War.

Shunkov V.N. Luftwaffe Aviation.

Ivanov V.P. Airplanes N.N. Polikarpov.

Roman Skomorokhov
